newsitem.title: PAKISTAN: Pakistan Telecom FY96 profit declines.
newsitem.headline: Pakistan Telecom FY96 profit declines.

text.p: The state-run Pakistan Telecommunication Co Ltd (PTCL) said on Monday its net profit for the year ending June 30, 1996 fell to 14.269 billion rupees from 16.835 billion a year-ago.
In a statement after its board of directors met in Islamabad, PTCL said total revenues increased to 37.779 billion rupees in 1995/96 from 33.060 billion in 1994/95.
It said the foreign exchange revenues of the company, which is up for sale, rose to 15.694 billion rupees from 13.209 billion in 1994/95.
But the operating profit for 1995/96 fell to 16.554 billion rupees from 17.667 billion in the previous year.
The board of directors recommended a cash dividend of 0.60 rupees per 10-rupee share compared to a dividend of 4.486 rupees per share in the year-ago period.
The statement said the profits were down because of provisions made for doubtful debts, charges for rentals and a central excise duty.
It said after making provisions of 1.54 billion rupees the net profit would be 12.72 billion rupees for 1995/96.
It said higher total revenue was due to installation of 249,442 new telephone connections, growth in long-distance calls and growth in international paid minutes.

PTCL was created on January 1, 1996 from state-run Pakisatan Telecommunication Corporation (PTC). It sold a million 100-share vouchers, about two percent of total equity, in Pakistan in August 1994. PTCL Global Depositary Receipts, about 10 percent of total equity, have been traded abroad since September 1994.

PTCL has a 25-year licence to provide a full range of telephone services and will enjoy a seven-year monopoly over basic telephone services in Pakistan. It is also exempt from paying corporate tax till June 1999.
The government plans to sell a 26 percent strategic stake in the PTCL.
